content.description: Fun warm-up climb starting with some shorter pillars followed by a vertical mid-section and finishing on less than vertical terrain.
content.location: Left route on the shorter brown columns on the right side of Astral wall. Starting by the base of the large tree on the right end of the wall.

climbs.name: Milky Way
climbs.fa: Andy Fitz, Bobby Flowers, Matt Kerns (2008)

content.description: One of my favorite routes in the Tieton.  Third-class up the left edge of the base slab to a very high first bolt, then start pulling...and pulling..and pulling...on mostly positive jugs.  It just keeps on getting better the higher you go; spectacular overhanging position at the finish.  Once you've dialed in the moves, it feels more like .10c, but I've heard most people call it .11a to onsight.
content.protection: Bolts; mid-point anchor.  Need two raps with 60 or 70-meter rope.

content.description: A long, epic journey through varied terrain. Start with three bolts of edging up the base slab, then launch into 100 feet of consistently overhanging climbing--mostly on jugs, but with a crimper crux.  Spectacular position!
content.protection: 17 bolts, plus anchor.  A single rap with a 70-meter BARELY makes the ground with stretch.  With a 60-meter, swing into the midway station of Milky Way (be sure to keep kicking off the wall while rapping).

content.description: This route graces the cover of the 2004 Ford/Yoder guide.  A somewhat powerful, gently overhaning start gives way to cruxes interspersed with good rests, with the most difficult crux (for me) coming just before a ledge near the top.  An optional second pitch (can be combined with first pitch) is much less climbed, but offers a fun 5.9 stemming corner.

climbs.name: Astral Cloud
climbs.fa: Andy Fitz, Doug Teague, Matt Kerns (2008)

content.description: The crux comes early, but it’s standard to combine the first "pitch" (.11a; 11 clips) and second pitch (.10c; 8 clips?) into one ~170’ lead with a buttload of 5.10 climbing.  Bring a draw for the mid-point anchor if you combine pitches.
content.protection: Bolts + two anchors.  2 raps required w/ 60 or 70-meter rope.

content.description: Very sustained...it's listed as a project in the book and sports a 20 foot run out from the last bolt to the anchors, possibly still needs a bolt?  The run out is easy climbing compared to the lower section, with huge holds and fun moves...The cruxes are hard, tenuous, sustained, and come one after another till the last bolt. This is quite simply the best sport route in Washington.....I hope your bag of tricks runs deep!
content.protection: One quick draws at the first bolt, fixed the rest of the way.
content.location: This is the route on the far right side of the wall.  It has fixed draws on it and is about 25-30 meters in length.  It has lockers at the top to lower off.

content.description: A long, moderate romp up a blocky face, ending at the top of a prominent arete.  There's a mini-crux turning a bulge down low, with the true crux (that's barely 5.10) coming in a series of bulges at the top.  A great warmup with nice position.
content.location: Obvious left-hand arete of the Astral Wall; visible from the trail on the hike down the gully.

climbs.name: Thanks Andy
climbs.fa: Matt Kerns, Jim Yoder, Kevin Buselmeier (2003)

content.description:
No matter how many times I climb this, I never seem to climb it the same way twice.  Fun crimps and jugs; a standard Astral Wall warm-up.

Not sure why Andy needs to be thanked...
content.location: First route right of West Arete

content.description: Varied climbing that will keep you thinking till the end.  Pumpy at the top!
content.protection: ~12 bolts; anchor.  Can rap with a 60-meter rope.
content.location: Seventh route from left (with Whitewashed the next route to the right).
